frqParts.text:
Read each question carefully. Show all your work for each part of the question. The parts within the question may not have equal weight.

A rod of length <math alttext="L" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>L</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> and mass <math alttext="uppercase M sub R" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>M</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>R</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> is placed on a table with a string attached. The string passes over a pulley and is attached to a hanger of variable mass <math alttext="lowercase m" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>m</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>. The string and pulley have negligible mass, and there is negligible friction in the pulley. The coefficients of static and kinetic friction between the rod and the table are <math alttext="mu sub s" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>μ</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>s</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="mu sub k" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>μ</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>k</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, respectively.

(a) On the dots below that represent the rod and the hanger, draw and label the forces (not components) that act on the rod and the hanger while the system is at rest. Each force must be represented by a distinct arrow starting on and pointing away from the dot.

(b) Derive an expression for the largest value of <math alttext="lowercase m" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>m</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> for which the system will remain at rest. Express your answer in terms of <math alttext="uppercase M sub R" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>M</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>R</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="mu sub s" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>μ</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>s</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="mu sub k" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>μ</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>k</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="g" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, and physical constants, as appropriate.
(c) The hanger with mass <math alttext="lowercase m" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>m</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> from part (b) is given a quick push downward, and the system begins to move.

i. Derive an expression for the acceleration <math alttext="a" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>a</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> of the rod after it begins to move. Express your answer in terms of <math alttext="uppercase M sub R" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>M</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>R</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="lowercase m" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>m</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="mu sub s" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>μ</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>s</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="mu sub k" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>μ</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>k</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="g" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, and physical constants, as appropriate.

ii. On the axis below, sketch a graph of the kinetic energy <math alttext="K" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>K</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> of the rod as a function of time <math alttext="t" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>.

The linear mass density <math alttext="lambda" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>λ</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> of the rod is given by the equation <math alttext="lambda of x, equals, beta times x squared" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>λ</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mi>β</mi><msup><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math>, where <math alttext="beta" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>β</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is a positive constant in units of <math alttext="kilograms per cubic meter" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>kg/</mtext><msup><mrow><mtext>m</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="x" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is the distance measured from the left end of the rod.

(d) Show that the position of the center of mass of the rod relative to its left end is equal to <math alttext="three fourths L" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></mfrac><mi>L</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>.
(e) The rod is separated at its center of mass into two parts, the left end and the right end.

i. Is the mass of the left end greater than, less than, or equal to the mass of the right end?
_____ Greater than _____ Less than _____ Equal to
Justify your answer.

ii. The two parts of the rod are reattached, and the original setup is run again. As the hanger is pulling the rod along the surface, is the force that the left end of the rod exerts on the right end greater than, less than, or equal to the force that the right end of the rod exerts on the left end?
_____ Greater than _____ Less than _____ Equal to
Justify your answer.
